text:
For the past 25 years we've been building
software to serve the water professional industry

So these are modelers, engineers, everyone
that deals with water infrastructure.
So, they'll want to know if we are, say,

putting in a change to the
drainage system in this area,
how big do we need to make the pipes?

If we get the average amount of rain,
what is that going to look like?

And then they can use that calculate
what is their current system is going to do?

We knew how to build a solution
with AWS, and we knew that they had

enough compute power
to stand behind what we built.
In order to create a fully managed solution
that scales with the needs, we wanted to make sure

that we leverage many serverless and
managed services as much as possible.

So if something can run inside a
Lambda, we will opt for a Lambda.
If a solution cannot really run on a Lambda,

we would use a container inside
Amazon ECS Fargate or Amazon ECS

We also, for communication, leverage
AWS EventBridge and SQS.
This allowed us to shrink the time from the point of customer
needing to venture into a large scale project
from let's say a year or year and a half to mere minutes.
Now the democratization or the accessibility
for customers to do their jobs in an easier,

seamless manner. They don't need to deal
with racking and stacking servers.

They just need to think
about their solutions

to their end
consumers, how they plan and build out

better and better infrastructure that
can cope with the changing environment

and with other projects that they
have within their day-to-day work.
